content:
Fascinating... Hunga Tonga had a (small) net _cooling_ effect on the climate, despite the big dollop of water vapour it injected into the stratosphere:
https://essopenarchive.org/users/523044/articles/741323-evolution-of-the-climate-forcing-during-the-two-years-after-the-hunga-tonga-hunga-ha-apai-eruption

There's either something missing in current observational climate data sets, or an unsuspected mechanism in the climate, or... well, that's it really, isn't it? Unless the aliens running the simulation we inhabit are japesters who like randomly changing physics. There might be a Nobel Prize for the person/team/group who can answer @ClimateOfGavin's question in his famous Nature comment (roughly, "WTF happened in 2023?")

For most of the last year I'd assumed it was HungaTonga + shipping aerosols + post-covid emission surge + ENSO + a randomly huge spike of natural internal variability, but that really looks lie it doesn't add up. So the next most likely, I guess(??) would be some very fast-responding earth system tipping point -- but it would have to be one that's not showing up clearly in current observations.

What is there that we're still not accurately measuring for most of the globe at a reasonably high frequency -- ocean currents??

#climatology #GlobalWarming #ClimateChange #2023_climate_anomalies

content:
A short time ago, the #Guardian published a survey of #IPCC #climate scientists. The consensus (77% of scientists) - #Earth is headed for at least 2.5 C of #GlobalWarming by the end of this century. (You can read about it here https://climatejustice.social/@ariadne/112404721518501046 )

What do you think the average temperature of our #planet will heat up to by 2100?

#Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #GlobalHeating #Klima #Klimakrise

card.title: Ariadne (@ariadne@climatejustice.social)
card.description:
Attached: 1 image

Major bad #ClimateCrisis news just published in today's #Guardian - "Exclusive: Planet is headed for at least 2.5C of heating with disastrous results for #humanity poll of hundreds of scientists finds - World‚Äôs top #climate scientists expect #GlobalHeating to blast past 1.5C target. 

Hundreds of the world‚Äôs leading climate scientists expect global temperatures to rise to at least 2.5C (4.5F) this century, blasting past internationally agreed targets and causing catastrophic consequences for humanity and the #planet, an exclusive Guardian survey has revealed.

Almost 80% of the respondents, all from the authoritative Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ( #IPCC), foresee at least 2.5C of global heating above preindustrial levels, while almost half anticipate at least 3C (5.4F). Only 6% thought the internationally agreed 1.5C (2.7F) limit will be met."

Many of the scientists envisage a ‚Äúsemi-dystopian‚Äù future, with #famine, #conflicts and mass #migration, driven by #heatwaves, #wildfires, #floods and #storms of an intensity and frequency far beyond those that have already struck.

Numerous experts said they had been left feeling hopeless, infuriated and scared by the failure of governments to act despite the clear scientific evidence provided.

‚ÄúI think we are headed for major societal disruption within the next five years,‚Äù said Gretta Pecl, at the University of Tasmania. ‚Äú[Authorities] will be overwhelmed by extreme event after extreme event, food production will be disrupted. I could not feel greater despair over the future.‚Äù

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/article/2024/may/08/world-scientists-climate-failure-survey-global-temperature

If a group of scientifically minded & engaged individuals aren't prepared to change their behaviour, what chance for the world?

content:
No matter how difficult and how painful it will prove to be, the only sensible choice right now is for the world to unite as one and agree that it is time to totally break our addiction to fossil fuels.

But this almost certainly will never happen. Even if the UN General Assembly voted in favor, it still would not happen.

Why? Because the US capitalist empire would never allow it, and the United Nations is essentially powerless to enforce anything.

And it‚Äôs not only the US. It‚Äôs also Norway, Sweden, Poland, Germany, France, Italy, Spain, the United Kingdom, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Brazil, Canada, Australia, India, China, Japan, South Korea ‚Äî on and on and on and on.

Virtually every nation-state in the world is far too invested in capitalism‚Äôs fever dream of endless growth to ever consider calling a halt or urging their citizens to adopt a truly carbon-free lifestyle.

Instead we‚Äôll simply carry on with Business As Usual, with politicians making their phony pledges and corporations doing their greenwashing, and with temperatures rising and ecosystems declining and species dying, while billionaires turn into trillionaires.

#USA #Politics #Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #Capitalism #Greenwashing

content:
Second of the three European EPR ( Evolutionary Power Reactor) #nuclear projects - #France #Flamanville - will be shortly connected to the grid. The projects caused many controversies due to long delays‚Ä¶ but they are getting completed:

  • üá´üáÆ Olkiluoto 3 ‚úÖ connected in 2023
  • üá´üá∑ Flamanville ‚úîÔ∏è finished, will be connected by end of 2024 : üá¨üáß Hinkley Point C üïì will be completed by 2027

The moment these projects get connected, they start delivering gigawatt-hours of low-carbon electricity to the grid, which is desperately needed for #ClimateChange prevention and mitigation.

Each of these has been criticised for delays (which is factually true but unfair) and ‚Äúhuge cost‚Äù (which is unfair and untrue).

Talking about the total investment cost in case of clean electricity sources that may live up to a century is a popular manipulation but what matters is LCOE.

It‚Äôs the cost of investment and operations divided by value of electricity produced over its life time. In case of nuclear power LCOE is quite low, in the range of $60/MWh because the relatively big initial costs is divided by decades of delivery of huge amounts of power. This is exactly the same case with very costly off-shore wind farms (e.g. the Doggerbank project) or huge solar farms (e.g. Ouarzazate in Morocco).

The reasons for delays are‚Ä¶ complex. This article[1] by Joris van Dorp is probably the best explainer to why exactly Hinkley Point C was delayed so much. It‚Äôs a mix of reasons, starting from ‚Äúfirst of kind‚Äù scale of the project to prohibitive and often absurd safety requirements lobbied after Fukushima by countries who saw an opportunity in replacing EU nuclear by Russian fossil gas. And they were absurd, for example because you don‚Äôt get earthquakes and tsunamis on the La Manche Channel.

And the reasons are complex, for example due to general UK attitude to funding infrastructure projects - they exclusively opt for private funding, which means the investors need to get a direct financial profit. Most people see the absurdity of private ownership of UK water utilities (which leads to no investments in the network and dumping of sewage into rivers by underregulated companies) but nobody sees the same absurdity in funding the electricity grid (which is in turn overregulated).

[^1]: https://medium.com/generation-atomic/the-hinkley-point-c-case-is-nuclear-energy-expensive-f89b1aa05c27

card.title: Senators Protect SEC Climate Disclosure Rule
card.description:
With more and more companies exposed to new and unforeseen risks from our intensifying climate crisis, many investors want to know whether or not their money, including retirement savings, are invested in companies that are exposed to climate financial risks.
 
 So in order to meet this demand and help provide consistent information to investors, in March of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) adopted a new rule to enhance and standardize climate-related disclosures by public companies.
 
 The new rule offers a modest step forward to let investors know whether or not their life savings are being invested in the biggest polluters on the planet, and how climate change might impact their retirement savings.
 
 Sadly, though, many in Congress would prefer to carry water for their fossil fuel industry contributors whose emissions created the climate crisis in the first place, and pretend that the problem doesn‚Äôt exist ‚Äì and they‚Äôve introduced Congressional Review Act (CRA) legislation to stop the SEC‚Äôs modest new rule from taking effect.
 
 What‚Äôs worse now is that if this CRA bill passes, it could prevent the SEC from ever proposing substantially similar regulations on climate-related financial risks -- making progress on climate far more difficult, and risking devastating financial consequences for retirement savers who want and need this information.
 
 Please click ‚ÄúStart Writing‚Äù to send a direct message to both your Senators today and tell them to vote NO on crippling the SEC‚Äôs ability to mandate climate disclosures for investors.

Republican attorneys general in 19 states have asked the U.S. Supreme Court to block several Democratic-led states from pursuing climate change lawsuits against the oil and gas industry in their own state courts.

The request comes as dozens of states and local governments have filed lawsuits alleging that fossil fuel companies deceived the public about their role in #ClimateChange

https://apnews.com/article/climate-change-lawsuits-oil-states-234edc15b4045ecb9eff0b5e27ca0aa5

card.title: Republican AGs ask Supreme Court to block climate change lawsuits brought by several states
card.description: Nineteen Republican state attorneys general have asked the U.S. Supreme Court to get involved in a dispute over climate-change lawsuits. The Republican attorneys general want the high court to block lawsuits filed by five Democratic-led states seeking damages from oil companies for their role in contributing to climate change. The GOP request targets lawsuits filed in state courts in California, Connecticut, Minnesota, New Jersey and Rhode Island. Those states are just a few of the dozens of state and local governments that have filed climate change lawsuits against the oil industry in recent years.

content:
Meanwhile, in #Finland:
The map of warnings looks pretty "fun" today. Special mentions to both potentially dangerous rain and wildfire in the same region, as well as the flood warnings and wildfire warnings in the same region!
It's been weeks since it rained properly and thus a bit of time since there was a single green blob on the map.
Weather! It's so normal!

#Weather #ClimateChange

media_attachments.description: A chart and map of warnings from the Finnish Meteorological Institute. The map shows the entirety of Finland covered in yellow warnings and some of Finland in orange. Yellow stands for potentially dangerous according to the side bar, orange stands for dangerous. Most of the country is covered in wildfire warnings. In multiple regions there is additionally either a flood warning or heavy rain warning. In the upper corner of the screen capture there are smaller maps with predictions for next week. By Thursday the little bit of orange will have overtaken almost half of the country.

content:
Images of #ClimateChange That Cannot Be Missed

I think the single best collection of images of the climate crisis I‚Äôve ever seen is the exhibit that will be up through early August at the #AsiaSociety, on Park Avenue

Co-curated by the celebrated photographer Susan Meiselas and the exhibition designer Jeroen de Vries, and led by the Asia Society‚Äôs Orville Schell, the longtime China watcher and correspondent for The #NewYorker (whose late brother Jonathan wrote ‚ÄúThe Fate of the Earth,‚Äù which first appeared in the magazine), ‚ÄúCoal + Ice‚Äù is an evolving project.

https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/images-of-climate-change-that-cannot-be-missed

media_attachments.description: Text Shot: But perhaps the single most powerful rendering of the climate crisis I‚Äôve ever seen is in a smallish square room on the second floor. Each of the four walls has been turned into a video screen, and they simultaneously play images collected over the past decade or so by the South African photographer Gideon Mendel. The films show people in places around the world returning to their flooded homes: there are Bengalis and Nigerians and Texans and Germans and many more, but the sequences are remarkably similar‚Äîpeople wading through chest-deep, stagnant floodwater, opening the front door of their houses, and then wandering into the waters inside. There‚Äôs no dialogue, just the overwhelming sense that something very wrong has happened.

content:
#Dallas blitzed by intense storms, disaster declared amid 1 million power outages

The Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex was rocked by severe #thunderstorms early Tuesday morning packing #hurricane-force #wind gusts and a deluge that turned roads into rivers.

By Brian Lada, AccuWeather meteorologist and staff writer

Published May 28, 2024

"A chaotic scene unfolded around Dallas early Tuesday morning as a line of intense storms blasted the city before sunrise, upending travel before the morning commute following the extended Memorial Day weekend. Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins issued a disaster declaration Tuesday morning in the wake of the severe storms.

"A 77-mph wind gust was clocked at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport at 5:47 a.m., CDT, contributing to more than 600 flight delays and 270 cancellations at the airport, according to FlightAware.

"The hurricane-force wind gusts caused havoc across the area, snapping tree limbs and bringing down power lines.

"Over 1 million homes and businesses across Texas were without power as of early Tuesday afternoon, according to PowerOutage.us, including nearly 350,000 outages in Dallas County. Power outages could last for several days in the hardest-hit areas, according to WFAA. "

https://www.accuweather.com/en/severe-weather/dallas-blitzed-by-intense-storms-disaster-declared-amid-1-million-power-outages/1654626

content:
Mariana Mazzucato: The ugly truth behind #ChatGPT: AI is guzzling resources at planet-eating rates

"When you picture the tech industry, you probably think of things that don‚Äôt exist in physical space, such as the apps and internet browser on your phone. But the infrastructure required to store all this information ‚Äì the physical datacentres housed in business parks and city outskirts ‚Äì consume massive amounts of energy. Despite its name, the infrastructure used by the ‚Äúcloud‚Äù accounts for more global greenhouse emissions than commercial flights. In 2018, for instance, the 5bn YouTube hits for the viral song Despacito used the same amount of energy it would take to heat 40,000 US homes annually."

#ClimateChange
https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/article/2024/may/30/ugly-truth-ai-chatgpt-guzzling-resources-environment
